results.title: Canon
results.creator_credit: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In its simplest form the canon is a kind of singing game, a round for voices where each singer picks up the words and tune, a beat or so after the preceding one. Norman McLaren and Grant Munro demonstrate, by animation and live action, how a canon works. A child’s blocks are used in a checkerboard to illustrate the form of Frere Jacques. Two additional canons specially written for the film by Eldon Rathburn are acted out. Five awards, including Toronto.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Grant Munro, Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Canine eyes for the blind
results.creator_credit: Hollywood Film Enterprises and Three Crown
results.brief_description: Deals with seeing-eye dogs, describing their use as guides for the blind, and how they are trained and selected. Points out that German Shepherd dogs usually make the best guide. Before training commences the dogs are checked for medical fitness and suitability and introduced to a normal domestic environment. They must undergo exacting tests with blindfolded instructors in city traffic; finally both dog and owner are taught to work together at the training centre.

results.title: Cancer: a research story
results.creator_credit: Larry Schwab, American Cancer Society, Dephoure Studios and Teleprograms
results.brief_description: Illustrates the story of the American Cancer Society’s basic research in cancer. This seeks to discover the causes, cures and controls of the disease. The narration is by the former Medical and Scientific Director of the Society, Dr Charles S. Cameron.

results.title: Cancer quest
results.creator_credit: American Cancer Society and Wisconsin University
results.brief_description: Through the experiences of a patient, the basic research projects being conducted at the McArdle Memorial Laboratory are depicted. The growth of normal tissue, the similarity between the growth stimulated by estrogen and the growth of cancerous tissue are shown, as is also the change from normal to cancerous as studied through azo dye effects. The effect of nutrition on cancer and the conversion of food into energy and cell structure in normal and cancer tissue is contrasted.

results.title: Cancer Institute
results.creator_credit: Geoffrey Thompson and Cine Service Productions
results.brief_description: The Peter MacCallum hospital is one of the most advanced cancer treatment centres in the world. As well as tracing its history, this film shows aspects of work being done by various sections of the hospital.

results.title: Cancer immunology
results.brief_description: Are there truly present, on the cancer cell, antigens different from those in the normal cell, i.e.cancer- specific antigens? If present, how can they be demonstrated? Moreover, through what immunologic mechanisms, and by what factors released from the host, are cancer cells destroyed? This film attempts to answer some of these questions.

results.title: Cancer by the carton
results.creator_credit: Harry R Smith, Leston Post and International Temperance Association
results.brief_description: The relationship between cigarette-smoking and lung cancer. Leading US surgeons and health authorities emphasise the parallel between increased smoking in recent decades and higher incidence of lung cancer. Also stressed is the shorter life of cigarette-smokers. The film dramatizes the story of a (fictitious) editor, who is trying to persuade the Board of a US magazine to publish the facts on cancer. Includes scenes of an actual lung operation, and of the diseased lung after removal.

results.title: Canberra today and tomorrow
results.brief_description: The rapidly developing capital city of Australia. Its beautiful site and many parks and gardens; national traditions enshrined in the Australian War Memorial, the Royal Military College of Duntroon and in Parliament House. The diplomatic missions, Canberra University College, research institutions. The corporate life of the city and plans for its future.

results.title: The Canberra Lake: Springtime sixty-four
results.creator_credit: Neil Howe, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Visatone (Australia)
results.brief_description: Canberra, the national capital of Australia, has a man-made lake in the centre of the city. We see a working model of the lake, dam, flood-gates, various transport routes and bridges. The lake, designed by Walter Burley Griffin, was opened at the end of 1964. Shows the official opening and the use of the lake for water sports.

results.title: Canadian profile
results.creator_credit: Allan Wargon, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: An informal portrait of the people of Canada at a time when modern technology is reaching into every phase of national life. Beginning with the fishermen of Newfoundland and ending with the Kitimat project on the west coast, the film explores the demands of a new machine age on people of diverse origins in whom the feeling for tradition is strong. In all there is evidence of change, adjustment, adaption as the industrial expansion becomes increasingly accelerated. Award: Toronto
